todos.title: Purpose
todos.body: Understanding the objective and being willing to complete it regardless of the emerging obstacles.

todos.title: Relative Superiority
todos.body: Smaller attacking force gains a decisive advantage over a larder or well-defended enemy.  Must be gained early in the engagement.  If relative superiority is lost, it is difficult to regain.

todos.title: Six Principles of Special Operations
todos.body: Simplicity, Security, Repetition, Surprise, Speed, Purpose.

todos.title: Security
todos.body: Preventing other side from gaining an advantage through foreknowledge of the impending attack.  Be careful who you share information with because it can get to the other side.  Security should be as tight as possible without impending planning or preparation.

todos.title: Four Phases of Operation
todos.body: Planning (simplicity), preparation (security and repetition), execution (surprise, speed, purpose), debriefing.

todos.title: Simplicity
todos.body: Limiting number of objectives, good intelligence (allows you to reduce the size of resources to only what is necessary), and innovation (allows you to avoid or eliminate obstacles or constraints).

todos.title: Speed
todos.body: In most cases, relative superiority is gained within five minutes of vulnerability point (when you begin to directly compete or attack).  Speed requires being small and lightly armed.

todos.title: Repetition
todos.body: Hones in individual and unit/team skills.  It includes full dress rehearsals.

todos.title: Surprise
todos.body: Gained through deception, distraction, confusion, delaying response, timing, and taking advantage of vulnerabilities.  Surprise does not alone give you the advantage.

todos.title: Innovation
todos.body: Includes new technology or unconventional tactics.
